Fig. 1 Lab-scale micro fixed reactor used for the reforming tests in this work. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD pattern of MCaO used as support and 5 % Ni-MCaO. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR analysis of fresh 5 % Ni- MCaO. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) SEM image of the particle surface. (B) Cross-sectional SEM image of the particle. (C)-(E) SEM-EDS mapping images of the agglomerate before reactor, Ca, Al and Ni dispersion respectively. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TEM (A and B) and STEM-EDS (C) images for the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Histogram and log-normal distribution fit curve of NiO particle sizes for fresh 5 % Ni-MCaO measured in TEM and STEM-EDS images using the ImageJ program. Murillo Environmental Research Group, Instituto de Carboquímica (Spanish National Research Council, ICB-CSIC), C/ Miguel Luesma Castán 4, Zaragoza 50018, Spain Environmental Research Group, Instituto de Carboquímica (Spanish National Research Council, ICB-CSIC) C/ Miguel Luesma Castán 4 Zaragoza 50018 Spain Environmental Research Group, Instituto de Carboquímica (Spanish National Research Council, ICB-CSIC), C/ Miguel Luesma Castán 4, 50018, Zaragoza, Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. In this work, a Ni-mayenite/CaO catalyst was synthetized, characterized and tested as a tar reforming catalyst for a gas with a composition typical of a biomass gasification process under lower temperature conditions than commercial reforming catalysts. Moreover, a reduced Ni content of 5 wt% was used and different operating variables (temperature, steam excess and presence of H2, CO2, CO and CH4) were studied. It was confirmed that regardless the variations in the composition of the gas entering the reforming reactor, the conversion of toluene (used as tar model compound) was complete at 700 ºC and high space velocities (ca. 90000 h−1 with respect to total gas and ca. 5 kgtoluene/kgreduced cat·h) with minimal coke deposition. In addition, reaction-regeneration cycles were conducted under different regeneration temperatures and gas mixtures for the removal of the deposited solid carbon. Finally, the catalytic activity of this novel catalyst was tested against several commercial catalysts at 700 ºC, demonstrating the superior performance of the 5 % Ni-mayenite/CaO compared to any of the Ni-based commercial catalysts studied. Graphical Abstract Keywords Tar Reforming Catalyst Mayenite Gasification Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Human activities generate significant amounts of waste, including agricultural and urban waste, the improper management of which has been demonstrated to have a detrimental effect on health and environment. According to the World Bank (2022), 2.24 billion tonnes of solid waste were produced in 2020, a figure that could increase by 73 % by 2050 due to population growth [1]. This problem is most acute in emerging countries, where 90 % of waste is incinerated or goes to landfill. Concurrently, the escalating demand for energy, the majority of which is currently met by fossil fuels [2], presents significant global challenges. In this context, waste could be harnessed as a sustainable source to produce hydrogen, synthetic fuels or other compounds through technologies such as pyrolysis and gasification. Gasification emerges as a promising solution for converting carbon-rich solid waste into synthesis gas (syngas), useful for biofuels and energy production due to its high calorific value [3]. The sorption-enhanced gasification (SEG) process, which uses CaO bed material, has been demonstrated as a potential technology for producing a tailored syngas with adequate contents of H₂, CO and CO₂ by acting on the CaO/biomass ratio and temperature [4,5]. In this sense, H2-rich syngas could be produced when operating under high CO₂ capture conditions (i.e. high CaO/biomass ratios and low temperatures), whereas more CO2 and CO suitable for a downstream synthetic natural gas (SNG) production process could be produced when reducing CO2 capture [5–8]. Nevertheless, the generation of pollutants is an inherent aspect of any gasification process, with tars being the primary pollutant formed. Characterized by a complex mixture of high molecular-weight hydrocarbon compounds, tars undergo a liquid phase transition at ambient temperature, resulting in fouling problems that can lead to clogging of pipes, heat exchangers, or fan/compressor systems. Conventional abatement strategies used in large-scale gasification plants typically rely on cold scrubbers, which achieve remarkable removal efficiencies through the condensation of these pollutants. The tar removal efficiency of such physical processes is close to 100 % [9]. However, if the syngas is to be used in a subsequent catalytic process, hot gas cleaning methods are preferred as they avoid the need for cooling and subsequent heating of the syngas, thereby mitigating the associated efficiency penalties. Hot tar cleaning techniques typically rely on high-temperature catalytic cracking or reforming reactors, using alkali, alkaline earth or noble and transition metal-based catalysts [9–11]. Nickel-based catalysts exhibit high activity in hydrocarbon cracking/reforming and are the preferred option due to their cost effectiveness compared to other noble metals used for this purpose [12]. In recent years, extensive research efforts have been devoted to the study of mayenite (Ca12Al14O33) and its derivatives as supports for tar reforming catalysts. The versatility of mayenite is due to its structural properties, which are defined by interconnected cages with a single electrical charge per unit cell. This structural composition consists of two molecules called [Ca24Al28O64]4+, accompanied by two additional oxide anions, commonly referred to as "free oxygen" [13]. The "free oxygen" present in mayenite plays a crucial role in the oxidation process, effectively oxidizing the carbon deposited on the catalyst. This oxidation mechanism prevents the accumulation of carbon, allowing it to operate at lower temperatures than other tar cracking/reforming catalysts, which are prone to coke deposition [14]. Various studies by different authors have explored the application of mayenite catalysts in the context of tar and hydrocarbons reforming from diverse gasification processes in laboratory-scale setups under conditions comparable to the present work [15–17]. Bracciale et al. conducted a study on toluene reforming at 700ºC with a catalyst containing 10 wt% Ni on mayenite, using a space velocity of 73750 h−1, a toluene concentration of 47 g/Nm3, and an steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of ca. 5. A 95 % conversion was achieved, which decreased over time [15]. De Caprariis et al. used a nickel loading of 20 wt% and conducted a toluene reforming study at 750 ºC with a space velocity of approximately 33000 h−1, obtaining a constant conversion of 98 % [16]. It is worth highlighting the toluene reforming work with a Ni/mayenite catalyst conducted by D’Orazio et al., where alternating cycles at temperatures between 650 and 700 ºC and a space velocity of approximately 138000 h−1 were performed, achieving approximately 99 % conversion during the first four cycles, with a nickel loading of 5 wt% [17]. Among the most commonly used catalyst supports are those with a large surface area, enhancing the dispersion of the active phase, and high thermal stability. These are mainly alumina (Al₂O₃) supports, or those with high alumina concentrations. Notable examples include the toluene reforming studies conducted by Zhu et al. [18] and He et al. [19], which achieved toluene conversions exceeding 90 % despite the high space velocity and high toluene concentration in the reactant gas, using nickel-based catalysts supported on Al₂O₃, with nickel loadings of 16 wt% and 10 wt% respectively, at temperatures ranging from 700 to 800ºC. Other commonly used supports include silica (SiO2), zirconium oxide (ZrO2), zeolites, activated carbon, olivine, dolomite, and spinels [20,21]. In this context, the main objective of this work is to synthetise, characterise and evaluate the catalytic activity of a Ni-based catalyst using mayenite as support, which could operate at lower temperatures and with a lower nickel load than the commercial reforming catalysts, while exhibiting minimal solid carbon deposition. Although other authors have published studies on the catalytic activity of Ni-based mayenite catalysts in tar reforming with similar Ni loading and similar temperatures [15–17,22], this study introduces a novel approach by examining higher space velocities and higher tar concentrations, using toluene as model tar compound. Additionally, this study explores the influence of various experimental parameters on catalytic activity, including temperature, moisture content in the feed gas and presence of permanent gases such as H2, CO2, CO and CH4. The effect of these variables on solid carbon deposition is also thoroughly examined. The catalytic performance of the Ni-based mayenite catalysts has been compared with that of other commercial Ni-based catalysts under identical experimental conditions. Finally, cyclic performance of the synthetized catalysts has been studied, including an optimization of the intermediate regeneration conditions needed for coke decomposition. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization In this work, a Ni-based catalyst using mayenite/CaO as a support was synthesized with the aim of achieving 5 wt% Ni content in the reduced catalyst. The mayenite/CaO support (MCaO) was prepared through a hydrothermal reaction followed by calcination. First, a physical mixture of Al(OH)3 (aluminium hydroxide, EssentQ®, Sharlab, Spain, purity > 95 %) and Ca(OH)2 (calcium hydroxide, powder, Pharmpur®, Sharlab, Spain, purity > 95 %) precursors was prepared in stoichiometric proportions, forming a suspension in isopropanol that was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Subsequently, the sample was then dried at 90ºC overnight. The next step was a hydrothermal reaction carried out in a 45 ml heating autoclave where 12 g of the solid mixture and 36 ml of water were introduced. The vessel was heated at 150 ºC (pressure 4–5 bars) for 5 h. The reaction product was then dried overnight at 115ºC, and then calcined in a muffle oven at 1000 ºC for 1 h (heating rate: 5 ºC/min) to obtain the mayenite/CaO phase, according to Manera et al. [23]. Finally, a wetness impregnation route was followed using a nickel nitrate solution (nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate, EssentQ®, Sharlab, Spain, purity > 95 %) at an appropriate concentration to obtain the desired final Ni content of 5 wt% (5 % Ni-MCaO). According to this impregnation method, 1 ml of a 0.89 mol/l nickel salt solution was added per gram of support and the resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min before drying at 150ºC overnight. The final calcination step was carried out at 900 ºC for 4 h (heating rate: 5 ºC/min). Manera et al. [23] calcined their Ni-mayenite/CaO catalyst at 1000 ºC after impregnation. However, in this study, it was observed that the catalyst's composition and catalytic activity remained similar when calcined at 1000ºC and 900ºC. Therefore, the lower temperature was selected. 2.1.1 Chemical characterization The freshly prepared catalyst was chemically characterised by the following techniques. The crystalline composition was determined by XRD analysis using a BRUKER AXS D8 Advance instrument. Ni content of the catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using a Spectroblue-EOP-TI FMT26 instrument. The sample was previously digested in lithium tetraborate for injection into the instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using a NETZSCH LIBRA F1 instrument to verify the Ni content results of the fresh catalyst obtained by ICP. In this experimental procedure, the catalyst was subjected to a heating period (heating rate of 25 ºC/min) in pure N2 up to 850ºC. A reduction step was then carried out at this temperature in a 10 vol% H2 /Ar gas flow for 20 min, followed by a final oxidation step in air for 20 min. The Ni content was calculated from the difference in mass between the oxidised and the reduced catalyst. The moles of oxygen lost during reduction were similar to the moles of oxygen gained in the subsequent oxidation, being equivalent to the moles of Ni. In addition, the reduction temperature of the nickel species present in the sample to Ni0 was determined by temperature programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. For this purpose, a certain amount of catalyst was exposed to a flow of approximately 50 Ncm3/min of a 10 vol% H2/Ar gas mixture and heated to a temperature of 950ºC (heating rate 5ºC/min). 2.1.2 Morphological characterization On the other hand, 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst was morphologically characterised by the following techniques. Firstly, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) coupled with energy- dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis was carried out to observe solid texture and to evaluate the appropriate distribution of the active phase on the support, using a Hitachi S-3400-N instrument. Subsequently, Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was carried out using a Tecnai T20 Transmission Electron Microscope (Thermofisher) operating at a working voltage of 200 kV, with images taken using a Veleta 2 K x 2 K CCD camera. The aim of this technique was to observe Ni crystal size. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) was carried out to further enhance the comprehensiveness of the analyses. This additional technique allowed to accurately identify the active phase particles and facilitate their diameter measurement using the ImageJ digital image processing program. The instrument used for the latter technique was a Tecnai F30 transmission electron microscope (Thermofisher) operating in STEM mode. For STEM, high angle annular dark field (STEM-HAADF) images were obtained using a HAADF detector (Fischione). In addition, to analyse the chemical composition of the materials, X-ray energy dispersive spectra (EDS) were obtained using an EDAX detector. 2.1.3 Physical characterization Finally, the support (MCaO) and the fresh catalyst (5 %Ni-MCaO) was physically characterised by N2 physisorption, Hg porosimetry and He picnometry. The solid surface area was determined by N2 physisorption (Micromeritics ASAP2020 instrument) at −196ºC and a pressure range from 0 to 1.27 bar, using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller equation in Microactive software. The porosity of the catalyst was determined by Hg porosimetry (POR-Hg) using a Micromeritics Autopore V9605 instrument. The results were processed using Microactive Autopore V9600 software. He pycnometry (PIC) was used to determine the density of the synthesised solid using a Micromeritics ACCUPYC II instrument. The purpose of comparing the analyses of both solids was to determine how the addition of the active phase affected the BET area, pore size and porosity. 2.1.4 Characterization of used catalyst TGA analysis (using a NIETZSCH LIBRA F1 instrument) was used to determine the solid carbon content on the used catalysts. In this experimental procedure, the catalyst sample underwent a heating step in N2 at a heating rate of 25ºC/min up to 850ºC. This was followed by an oxidation step in air at this temperature for 15 min and a final reduction step in a 10 % H2/Ar gas flow for 15 min. The mass of coke deposited was determined by weight loss during oxidation, considering the weight gain associated with nickel oxidation. Finally, the catalyst used in the reaction-regeneration cycles at 700ºC and 850ºC was also examined through TEM to determine the NiO crystal size after cycling. Additionally, the catalyst used in the reaction-regeneration cycles at 850ºC (Test 1), after undergoing a final oxidation stage, was analyzed using XRD to evaluate the stability of the support and a SEM-EDS analysis was performed to verify that the active phase had not migrated to the surface of the catalyst particle. 2.2 Lab-scale micro-fixed bed reactor and catalyst testing Catalyst performance tests were conducted in a lab-scale micro-fixed bed reactor, illustrated in Fig. 1. The reactor consists of a 6 mm inner diameter quartz tube positioned in a cylindrical electrically heated furnace. The furnace temperature is regulated using a thermocouple located at the top of the solid bed. The feed gas composition included N2, H2, CO2, CO, and CH4, which were introduced via mass flow controllers, together with H2O controlled by a liquid mass flow controller and evaporated in an oven at 390ºC after mixing with the rest of the gas mixture, as shown in Fig. 1. Toluene (C7H8) was used as a model compound for tar in this study and its flow rate was controlled by an HPLC liquid pump. The reactor has a bypass line which is used to stabilise the feed gas mixture before it is introduced into the reactor. All pipes are equipped with electric heaters to maintain an outlet temperature of 390ºC to prevent condensation of H2O and toluene. The gas composition at both the inlet and outlet of the reactor was analysed by gas chromatography using a Varian CP-3800 chromatograph, which has a valve injection system with 2 loops. One loop is discharged to the flame ionization detector (FID) channel, used for the determination of C7H8 and C6H6, while the other is discharged to the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) channel, used for the quantification of permanent gases and light hydrocarbons (i.e., N2, H2, CO2, CO, CH4, C2H6, and C2H4). Two packed columns, HAYESEP Q (2.00 m length and 1/8” OD) and MOLE SIEVE 13X (1.83 length and 1/8” OD), were used for the TCD channel. A CP-SIL 5 capillary column (15 mm length and 0.32 mm internal diameter) was used for the FID channel. The temperature programme of the column oven was maintained isothermal at 50 ºC for 13 min, and the carrier gas for the columns was Ar. The TCD was maintained at 175ºC, and the FID at 150ºC. Table 1 summarises the experiments conducted in this study to evaluate the performance of the catalyst. It should be noted that in some experiments (E0-E2, E7) only toluene, H2 and H2O were included in the feed gas, and large H2 contents of ca. 92 vol% were used to be able to draw the H2O to the evaporator. For the remaining tests (E4, E5 and E6) CO2, CO and CH4 were gradually introduced based on the typical contents obtained in SEG conditions in the recent published literature [5,6,24,25]. A catalyst particle size of 200–400 µm was used for all the experiments, except for the cycle tests where a particle size of 600–800 µm was used for subsequent process scaling in a syngas cleaning system downstream of a TRL-5 gasification pilot plant. All experiments started with a catalyst reduction step at 700ºC using a 24 vol% H2/N2 gas flow for 1 h. Following this reduction step, the feed gas composition to the reforming stage was stabilised through the bypass and its composition monitored by gas chromatography (GC). Once stable, the gas mixture was passed through the reactor. As shown in Table 1, different reforming temperatures (650–700ºC) and steam concentrations were used in the experiments to define the operating window for the catalyst. The steam content in the feed gas was quantified by the steam-to-carbon ratio (S/C), which represents the molar flow of H2O fed per mole of C introduced into the reactor (i.e. C in toluene, CO2, CO and CH4). In all experiments, the total gas space velocity was kept at ca. 90000 h−1, while the space velocity for toluene was kept at about 5 kgtoluene/kgreducedcat·h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results for fresh catalyst Chemical and morphological and physical characterisation of the fresh catalyst was carried out to gain a better understanding of the support structure and to ensure that the synthesis and impregnation methods of the active phase were suitable and consistent with those previously published in other studies [15,26–29]. The XRD patterns of both the mayenite/CaO support (MCaO) and 5 % Ni-MCaO are shown in Fig. 2. In both cases, mayenite reflections were shown in several peaks such as 2Ɵ= 18.0º, 29.7º, 33.3º, 36.6º and 41.1º [26]. CaO reflections were identified at 2Ɵ= 32.2º, 37.4º and 53.9º [27]. In 5 % Ni-MCaO, the primary Ni chemical species consisted of NiO, with reflections appearing at 2Ɵ= 37.2º, 43.3º and 62.9º [28]. It was concluded that Ni(NO3)2 present in the solution during wetness impregnation was converted to NiO (bunsenite) during the calcination process performed after impregnation. No reflections corresponding to Ni aluminates were detected. A plausible mechanism for the formation of mayenite from hydroxides is the formation of a hydrated precursor called hydrogarnet, Ca3Al2(OH)12 through an hydrothermal reaction, whose subsequent calcination at 1000°C results in a mixture of mayenite and CaO, according to Kazi et al. [29]. The presence of hydrogarnet was confirmed by XRD analysis of the solid obtained from the hydrothermal reaction as shown in the diffractogram in Figure S1. In addition to XRD, the fresh catalyst was analysed by ICP-OES to determine the Ni content. As noticed in Table 2. ICP results indicate a content of 5.0 wt% in the catalyst, which is consistent with the content of Ni that underwent reduction and oxidation in the TGA analysis. The results of the H2-TPR analysis ( Fig. 3) showed a maximum reduction peak at 486 ºC, with two minor peaks observed at 690ºC and 814ºC. The large peak could correspond to the reduction of NiO with little or moderate interaction with the support, while the peak with a maximum at 690ºC could be attributed to NiO which has a greater interaction with the support. The small peak observed at 814ºC could correspond to the reduction of minor quantities of NiAl2O4 spinel not detected by XRD analysis [28]. Overall, a reduction temperature of 700ºC was established in order to ensure that most of the Ni is reduced, since the main reduction peak ranges from ca. 360–650ºC. The morphological characterisation of the catalyst was carried out using different electronic microscopy techniques. Fig. 4(A) shows a standard SEM image capturing the characteristic features of the surface of the fresh catalyst. Fig. 4(B-E) shows cross-sectional views of a catalyst particle obtained by dispersing the catalyst in an acrylic resin and then subjecting it to precise cutting. Fig. 4(C-E) shows the elemental distribution of calcium (Ca), aluminium (Al) and nickel (Ni) within the solid catalyst. The uniform distribution of Ca and Al indicates a uniform dispersion of mayenite and calcium oxide (CaO). Fig. 4(E) also shows that Ni is uniformly distributed throughout the particle, a remarkable achievement given the extremely low content of this metal used. This observation underlines the precision and effectiveness of the distribution process, particularly when dealing with minimal concentrations of Ni. Fig. 5 shows the TEM and STEM-EDS images for the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst. In all cases, the presence of hexagonal particles attributed to NiO was observed using the EDS technique. The diameter of at least 250 NiO particles was measured, and a statistical study of the particle size distribution was made, as shown in the histogram in Fig. 6. The mean particle size measured was 26 ± 8 nm. Finally, Table 2 shows the results of the physical characterisation techniques carried out. Figure S2 shows the POR-Hg results obtained from the catalyst support (MCaO). As shown in the figure, the solid has a predominantly macroporous structure, with an average pore diameter of 4175 nm. These macropores facilitate Hg intrusion due to their size, and the overall high porosity of ca. 67.3 % suggests that most of the volume of the solid is occupied by pores. In addition, a small secondary distribution of macropores and mesopores was observed (distribution between ca. 11 and 106 nm of pore size diameter) in Figure S2 (left), with an average diameter of ca. 39 nm. It is also possible to observe a minimal distribution of mesopores with an average pore diameter of 10 nm. After Ni impregnation, the total pore volume distribution of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst undergoes a significant transformation as appreciated in Figure S3. Instead of three distinct pore distributions, as in the MCaO support, a single pore diameter distribution is now observed, centred at a mean pore diameter of ca. 134 nm. This suggests that the impregnation process has modified the pore structure, reducing the maximum size of the macropores and extending their range towards smaller sizes, which generates a partial overlap with the larger diameter mesopores, with the disappearance of the small diameter mesopore distribution. As a result, the total porosity decreases to ca. 42.3 % compared to ca. 67.3 % for the unimpregnated MCaO support, suggesting that the Ni impregnation has reduced the available pore volume, probably due to the occupation and possible partial clogging of the pores by the active phase. These changes are in correlation with the results obtained in N2 physisorption. Figure S4 shows the adsorption isotherms obtained for the MCaO and 5 % Ni-MCaO solids. As appreciated, the N2 adsorption isotherms obtained for both solids are a combination of type II and type IV isotherms, since type II is associated with macroporous materials. However, they show a hysteresis loop related to the presence of mesopores (type IV isotherm), as observed in the POR-Hg results. Compared to the MCaO support, the 5 % Ni-MCaO solid showed a lower volume of N2 adsorbed, indicating a decrease in the total pore volume due to the incorporation of the active phase. In addition, BET area decreased from ca. 18 to ca. 11 m2/g, supporting the decrease in pore volume after Ni impregnation. Similar BET area was found by Bracciale et al. [15]. Other supports, such as alumina or zeolites [18,30], offer a higher BET surface area, promoting the dispersion of the active phase and preventing large deposits of solid carbon. However, they do not possess the oxidative capacity for solid carbon removal that mayenite exhibits. Finally, PIC analysis of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst showed a powder density of 2.24 g/cm3. 3.2 Catalyst performance under steam reforming conditions The catalytic activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst was investigated under various conditions of temperature and feed gas composition, in particular the influence of H2, CO, CO2, and CH4, as shown in Table 1. Prior to this study, a blank test was performed to determine the catalytic activity of the MCaO support in the toluene reforming reaction. In this test, a certain amount of MCaO equivalent to the catalyst used in the experiments was introduced into the reactor under the conditions for E1 outlined in Table 1. No catalytic activity of MCaO was observed regarding toluene conversion, confirming the absence of catalytic effects of the support, at least under the operating conditions investigated in this study. 3.2.1 Effect of temperature and S/C ratio Fig. 7 shows the gas yield and solid carbon deposition for experiments E1, E2, and E7 carried out at different temperatures and S/C ratios. According to the information included in Table 1, it is worth noting that in these three experiments the conversion of toluene was complete. The effect of temperature can be assessed by comparing experiments E2 and E7 (at 700ºC and 650ºC, respectively), while the effect of S/C can be observed between experiments E1 and E2 (at ca. 2.6 and 3.5, respectively). In these experiments, total gas yield was calculated from the flow of N2 introduced with the feed gas, which remained constant through the reactor, and its content in the product gas determined by GC-MS. Then, each individual gas yield was calculated using the calculated total gas yield and the composition, which was then divided by the kilograms of toluene at the inlet. Solid carbon deposition rate was calculated by dividing the total amount of solid carbon deposited on the catalyst, measured by TGA analysis, by the total reaction time and the amount of reduced catalyst. The obtained results show that increasing the temperature from 650ºC to 700ºC leads to a decrease in CH4 yield and an increase in H2 and CO production of about 28 % and 67 %, respectively. This phenomenon is attributed to the CH4 reforming reaction (Eq. 1). The CO2 yield remains relatively constant, possibly because CO2, although formed by a water gas shift reaction (Eq. 2), acts as a gasifying agent, decomposing solid carbon deposited on the catalyst surface into CO according to Eq. 3 [31]. In addition, the increase in temperature from 650ºC to 700ºC results in a decrease in carbon formation due to the enhancement of carbon gasification reactions with temperature (Eqs. 3 and 4). Specifically, the calculated solid deposition rate decreases from about 0.60μmol/(mgred cat ∙ min) at 650ºC to about 0.09μmol/(mgred cat ∙ min) at 700ºC (calculated as the ratio of the total solid carbon deposited on the catalyst, determined by TGA, to the reaction time), as shown in Fig. 7. (1) C H 4 + H 2 O ↔ C O + 3 H 2 Δ H ° R = + 206 k J / m o l (2) C O + H 2 O ↔ H 2 + C O 2 Δ H ° R = − 41 k J / m o l (3) C + C O 2 ↔ 2 C O Δ H ° R = + 173 k J / m o l (4) 2 C + H 2 O ↔ H 2 + C O Δ H ° R = + 131 k J / m o l Concerning the influence of the S/C ratio (E1 and E2), CH4 reforming was improved by increasing the value of the S/C ratio, as expected from Eq. 1, increasing the H2 yield by about 28 %. The water-gas shift reaction (Eq. 2) was also favoured, leading to an increase in CO2 yield of about 39 % and maintaining a similar value for CO yield. In both cases, the rate of solid carbon deposition was similar, indicating that the effect of the S/C ratio on carbon deposition may not be as influential as that of temperature. 3.2.2 Effect of H2, CO2, CO and CH4 in the reacting mixture Fig. 8 shows four experiments to investigate the effect of H2 concentration (E0 and E1) and the presence of CO2 (E1 and E4) and CO (E1 and E5) in the feed gas mixture. For all these four experiments, toluene conversion was complete as shown in Table 1. In experiments E0 and E1, it was observed that reducing the H2 concentration in the gas stream entering the reactor favours methane reforming, thereby increasing the H2 yield. Moreover, reducing the H2 content in the feed gas favoured the water gas shift reaction, resulting in the production of CO2 and a reduction in CO. The presence of CO2 in the feed mixture (E1 and E4) promotes the reverse water-gas shift reaction, leading to an increase in the amount of CO in the product gas and subsequently inhibiting the CH4 steam reforming reaction (Eq. 1). Both effects result in an increase in the CH4 yield from 0.14 to 0.57 Nm3/kgtoluene and a decrease in the H2 yield of about 37 %. By varying the CO concentration at the reactor inlet (E1 and E5), it can be seen that the CH4 yield increases significantly, from 0.14 Nm3/kgtoluene in the absence of CO in experiment E1 to 0.89 Nm3/kgtoluene when 13.8 vol% CO (N2-free dry gas) is present in the feed gas. This is due to the inhibitory effect of CO on CH4 reforming (Eq. 1), which causes the accumulation of CH4. As appreciated in the Fig. 8, the solid carbon deposition rate remained more or less constant in these experiments, ca. 0.04–0.10 μmol/(mgred cat ∙ min), suggesting that the introduction of H2, CO and CO2 into the reactor inlet gas stream, as well as the increase in the S/C ratio studied in the previous section, do not have a significant influence on this phenomenon, as the temperature does. The introduction of CH4 into the reactant gas mixture resulted in a decrease in the S/C ratio with respect to hydrocarbons, since CH4 is a hydrocarbon undergoing reforming. Fig. 9 Left shows the results of experiment E6, where the activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst in toluene removal was investigated in the presence of 9.4 % CH4 N2-free dry gas feed. It can be seen that the CH4 conversion gradually decreased from the beginning of the reaction. However, the conversion of toluene became incomplete after 2.75 h from the start of the reaction, possibly due to a progressive accumulation of solid carbon on the catalyst surface. This accumulation led to the appearance and gradual increase in the flow of toluene and benzene at the reactor outlet until the end of the experiment. The decrease in catalytic activity was also evidenced by an increase in the water flow rate (calculated by solving the mass balance to hydrogen), which was not consumed due to the impairment of the steam reforming reaction of hydrocarbons (Eqs. 1 and 5). The gradual increase in coke deposition (calculated by the mass balance to carbon) resulted from a coating of the Ni crystals by solid carbon layers [32]. (5) C 7 H 8 + 7 H 2 O ↔ 7 C O + 11 H 2 Δ H ° R = + 231 k J / m o l Fig. 9 Right shows the results of experiment E8, which was carried out under similar conditions to E6 but without toluene at the reactor inlet feed gas (Table 1). This aim of this study was to confirm that the catalyst showed activity in methane reforming. CH4 conversion decreased from about 85 % to about 73 % over the approximately 3.5 h duration of the experiment. This decrease in CH4 conversion was further confirmed by a decrease in the CO and CO2 output flow rates (Eqs. 1 and 2), which decreased by approximately 58 % and 50 %, respectively, from the beginning to the end of the test. 3.2.3 Cyclic performance of the catalyst In order to assess the durability and stability of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst, multiple reforming/regeneration cycles were carried out. Reaction conditions were maintained similar to those of the E2 experiment (i.e., 700ºC, S/C= 2.56, as observed in Table 1) and each reaction stage was maintained for 1.5 h. The operating conditions evaluated for the regeneration stage are summarised in Table 3. Regeneration was initially carried out by a calcination/combustion stage using an O2/N2 mixture as feed gas to oxidise the coke produced and to decompose CaCO3. Firstly, an operating temperature of 850ºC was investigated (Test 1). Under these conditions, complete toluene conversion was achieved in only 6 cycles. Fig. 10 shows the log-normal distribution fit curves of NiO crystal size obtained from a histogram illustrating the relative frequency of particle size for both the fresh and used catalysts in the cycles with O2/N2 regeneration. The histograms were created based on NiO crystals measured using ImageJ from TEM images. A distribution towards larger particle sizes was observed in the catalyst used in the reaction-regeneration cycle Test 1. The mean crystal size increased from 26 ± 8 nm in the fresh catalyst to 101 ± 31 nm in the catalyst used after performing 6 reforming/regeneration cycles under the conditions shown in Test 1 (Table 3). The observed sintering process was favoured by the high temperature used during regeneration [33], which explains the decrease in catalytic activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO after 6 cycles. Figure S5 shows the XRD diffractogram to the catalyst used in Test 1 after 6 reaction-regeneration cycles. As noticed revealed the absence of CaO and indicated exclusively the presence of mayenite and NiO in crystalline phase, with diffraction peak intensities higher than those observed in the fresh catalyst (Fig. 2). This phenomenon suggests that the catalyst has undergone a significant chemical structural transformation over the cycles. The absence of CaO can be explained by its reaction with the alumina contained in the amorphous phase of the material, which would have favoured the formation of additional mayenite. This compound is known for its thermal stability and potential catalytic properties, so its presence in higher proportion would suggest a structural evolution of the material. Nevertheless, although there is an increment in the formation of mayenite, the results of the NiO particle measurements from TEM images also show a sintering phenomenon of the active phase of the catalyst (Fig. 10). Sintering causes agglomeration of the active particles, may negatively affect the availability of catalytic sites and so the activity of the catalyst. Asconfirmed by the cyclic performance test, the activity loss generated by sintering has exceeded any possible benefit associated with the formation of mayenite. These findings indicate that, although there has been a structural transformation, it did not help maintain the material's catalytic efficiency. The SEM-EDS analysis conducted on the used catalyst after 6 reaction-regeneration cycles (Test 1) revealed a homogeneous distribution of the active phase, with no evidence of migration of Ni to the catalyst surface ( Fig. 11). Therefore, the only issue associated with the active phase is the sintering process. In order to reduce the sintering phenomena, the following regeneration conditions were evaluated at 700ºC. In Test 2 the regeneration consisted of a coke oxidation step using an O2/N2 feed gas, but the main difference with Test 1 is that in Test 2 the CaO remains carbonated. Under the conditions of Test 2, a total of 20 reforming/regeneration cycles were performed without any loss of catalytic activity. Fig. 10 shows that the NiO crystal size increased from 26 ± 8 nm to 62 ± 19 nm after these 20 cycles. Throughout the cycles performed under these conditions, the composition of the product gas remained similar and stable, similar to the gas produced in E2 (i.e., 65 vol% H2, 2 vol% CH4, 18 vol% CO, and 15 vol% CO2 on a N2-free dry gas basis). With the aim of reducing the cycle time and thus avoiding the subsequent reduction step required at the end of the oxidation stage, regeneration conditions based on a H2O gasification operation were also studied (Tests 3–5). Such gasification conditions were performed at 700 ºC using a steam flow in the presence of hydrogen to prevent oxidation of the Ni-MCaO catalyst. Three different gas mixtures were tested in this case: a similar gas flow rate of approximately 135 Ncm3/min with about 30 vol% water steam and about 6 vol%, 10 vol% and 25 vol% H2 in N2. Despite these efforts, progressive solid carbon accumulation was observed in all three cases as the rate of coke deposition exceeded the rate of coke gasification by steam. This fact resulted in a significant pressure drop in the quartz micro-fixed bed lab-scale reactor, leading to the exclusion of these regeneration conditions. 3.2.4 Catalyst testing under SEG gasification and O2/steam gasification conditions Experiments E3 and E4 were carried out using reactant gas mixtures with concentrations of steam, H2 and CO2 similar to those found in gases produced by specific gasification processes. E3 represented syngas conditions typical of O2/steam gasification (i.e. lower H2 and higher CO2 contents), while E4 corresponded to a sorption-enhanced gasification process (i.e. high H2 content with reduced CO2 presence and larger steam content). Specific feed gas composition used in these experiments can be found in Table 1. These experiments aimed to assess the catalytic activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst under conditions resembling specific gasification processes, both operating at 700 ºC. Fig. 12 shows the individual product gas yields and the solid carbon deposition rate obtained in these experiments. Before analyzing the effect of the gasification conditions, it worth noting that in both experiments toluene conversion reached was complete (Table 1). Comparing the E3 and E4 tests, a higher gas yield was observed when the feed gas had a composition similar to an O2/steam process (E3) compared to a feed gas with a SEG composition (E4). As shown before, the presence of H2 in the feed gas inhibits methane reforming and water gas shift reactions (Eqs. 1 and 2) since this compound is one of the products of such reactions. In this sense, the reaction conditions in E4, corresponding to a larger H2 content in the feed gas, would not be as favorable as those in E3 for promoting reforming reactions, resulting in this way in a lower gas yield of H2 and CO in E4 that are the main products of such reactions. In addition, the presence of a larger content of CO2 in E3 could promote the dry reforming reaction of CH4 (Eq. 6), which would also contribute to the reduced CH4 yield observed in E3. Finally, concerning solid carbon deposition, it can be noticed that gasification environments explored in this study did not influence the formation of solid carbon, which resulted in a similar deposition rate of ca. 0.10 μmol/(mgred cat ∙ min). (6) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 C O + 2 H 2 Δ H ° R = + 247 kJ/mol 3.2.5 Benchmark of the new Ni-based catalysts for toluene reforming The activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst was compared with that of three commercial Ni-based catalysts under similar E2 test conditions, which represents the minimum temperature and the minimum S/C ratio at which the toluene conversion was complete and the reactor pressure drop due to coke deposition was minimal. These commercial Ni-based catalysts had different Ni loads. Therefore, particles of these solids in the range of 200–400 µm were diluted in silicon carbide (SiC) to adjust these catalysts to the same space velocity with respect to nickel (ca. 104 kgtoluene/kgNi·h). Fig. 13 shows the evolution of toluene conversion along time for the three commercial Ni-based catalysts and the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst developed in this work under E2 test conditions. As shown in Fig. 13, total toluene conversion was achieved for the 5 % Ni-MCaO catalyst during the nearly 4-hour duration of the experiment. However, the catalytic activity of Commercial 1 and Commercial 3 (both designed for steam reforming of tars) decreased approximately 65 min after the start of the reaction. Despite this, Commercial 1 exhibited lower catalytic activity than Commercial 3, but the latter solid exhibited significant coke deposition that hindered the progress of the experiment. Commercial 2 (designed for steam reforming of methane) completely lost its catalytic activity 26 min after the start of the reaction. The superior catalytic activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO synthetized in this work was confirmed based on the results obtained under conditions of high space velocities at 700ºC. This result represents a significant step forward in the optimization of the cleaning pathway of biomass and waste gasification plants. Mayenite has proven to be an effective support for Ni-based catalysts in steam reforming of tars, standing out for its ability to operate efficiently at 700ºC. Its unique properties have generated significant interest, particularly when compared to traditional catalytic supports, which require higher operating temperatures to achieve similar efficiency. For example, Corella et al. reported the catalytic activity of several commercial Ni-based catalysts in the tar reforming process during the air gasification of pine wood chips. The catalysts evaluated included ICI 46–1, R-67, RKS-1, and G1–50, with Ni loadings ranging from 12 to 50 wt%. To achieve an almost complete tar reforming, temperatures close to 800ºC were used, with space velocities similar to those studied in the present work [34]. One of its main advantages is its thermal stability, allowing it to withstand high temperatures without undergoing structural changes. This characteristic is essential for its durability and efficiency in catalytic tar reforming, contributing to a more cost-effective process with lower susceptibility to unexpected failures. However, the most remarkable feature of mayenite lies in its ability to oxidize the solid carbon deposited on the catalyst. Due to its high oxygen transfer capacity within its crystalline structure, it maintains consistent catalytic activity over extended periods, preventing deactivation caused by coke accumulation during reforming reactions [13,14]. Furthermore, its oxidative capacity enables operation at lower temperatures than conventional ones (around 800 ºC or more) [35]. As a result, a smaller amount of active phase is required to achieve optimal efficiency in tar reforming. Ni-based catalysts supported on mayenite, being able to operate at 700°C, are less prone to sintering, a phenomenon that reduces the dispersion of the active metal and negatively impacts process efficiency. Finally, the performance of the 5 % Ni-MCaO synthetized in this work is compared with other Ni-based catalysts reported in the literature for toluene reforming. Table 4 summarizes the studies found in the literature under relatively realistic toluene reforming conditions, which are scalable to a cleaning system located in a gasification plant, with toluene being the model or major tar compound. As appreciated in Table 4, there is a significant number of Ni-based mayenite catalysts in the literature for this application, whose Ni content ranges between 3 wt% and 20 wt%. Several works focus on a Ni load of 5 wt% or lower [17,22,36] but all of them deal with more favorable conditions of toluene content in the feed gas than in this work (i.e. 4–22 g/Nm3 in the feed gas vs. 87 g/Nm3 in this work). Li et al. [22] prepared two catalysts with 3 wt% and 5 wt% of Ni load and test their activity at similar conditions of temperature, space velocity and toluene content (i.e. 800ºC, 6000 h−1 and 4 g/Nm3) in the presence of H2S. According to these authors, both materials reached maximum toluene conversion in the first 60 min but lost their activity after that time, probably due to the poisoning with sulfur. Focusing on those catalysts with similar Ni load to that used in this work, Savuto et al. [36] obtained promising results of conversion for toluene and naphthalene at 800 ºC and gas space velocities of up to 20000 h−1, reaching 95 % of conversion for 480 min. D’Orazio et al. [17] used temperatures more similar to those used in this work (i.e. 650–700 ºC) and conducted reaction-regeneration cycles. These authors observed that the catalyst began to lose activity by the fourth cycle despite the very high S/C ratio used, probably due to the high calcination/combustion temperature of 800ºC, which may have caused sintering of the Ni crystals, as observed in the present work. Larger Ni loads have allowed operating under more exigent conditions of temperature and space velocities (700–750 ºC and > 30000 h−1) but still using lower toluene contents than those used in this work [15,16]. According to Bracciale et al. [15], the synthesis method used for the preparation of the Ni-based mayenite catalysts influenced the performance reached. Regardless of the synthesis method used for the support, whether dispersion of boehmite or calcination of the stoichiometric mixture of aluminum and calcium hydroxides, the synthesis variable that most influenced the activity of the Ni/mayenite catalyst was the method of addition of the active phase. Catalysts impregnated using the wet method initially exhibited higher catalytic activity, which diminished over time. One-step addition method provided a toluene conversion of approximately 65 %, which remained constant throughout the entire reaction time. Finally, alternative Ni-based catalysts supported on Al2O3 or zeolites have been proposed in the literature [18,19,37]. He et al. [19] and Zhu et al. [18] achieved toluene conversions exceeding 90 % at temperatures between 700 and 800ºC and space velocities ranging from 60000 to 65000 h−1, with a nickel loading of 10–20 wt%. The high catalytic activity of nickel catalysts on Al2O3 can be attributed to the high porosity of the support, which enhances the distribution of active sites and prevents the formation of large solid carbon deposits [38]. The disadvantage of the nickel catalyst on HZSM zeolite compared to other catalysts, such as those supported on Al2O3 or mayenite, is the generation of a greater amount of solid carbon on the catalyst surface due to its acidity [39], despite its high surface area. In summary, despite having a low surface area, the solid carbon oxidation capability of mayenite allows the catalytic activity of Ni/mayenite catalysts to be superior at lower temperatures, higher space velocities referring to tars, and lower active phase loadings compared to other catalysts that do not exhibit this quality. 4 Conclusions The 5 % Ni-MCaO material proved to be an excellent catalyst for the complete reforming of toluene in the temperature range of 650–700ºC, making it particularly suitable for gas cleaning in gasification processes. Minimal coke deposition occurred at 700ºC, which can be slightly mitigated by increasing the steam content and the concentration of CO2 and CO in the reactor feed gas. Among these factors, reforming temperature emerged as the most influential variable on coke deposition, with a decreasing trend with increasing temperature. The introduction of CH4 into the reactant gas mixture, as a hydrocarbon subject to reforming by the catalyst, resulted in a reduction of the S/C ratio and a loss of catalytic activity. Different regeneration conditions were investigated with the aim of cyclic use of the catalyst. Optimal regeneration conditions involved combustion at 700 ºC followed by reduction with H2/N2 at the same temperature, which allowed the catalyst to maintain its activity over 20 reforming/oxidation/reduction cycles. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of the 5 % Ni-MCaO solid was evaluated under different syngas composition scenarios (i.e. O2/steam and SEG gasification conditions) at 700ºC, demonstrating complete toluene reforming with minimal coke deposition in both cases. Finally, the performance of the synthetised 5 % Ni-MCaO solid was compared with that reported in the literature for other Ni-based catalysts under toluene reforming conditions. Despite the considerable number of Ni-based mayenite catalysts identified in the literature, the performance of the developed catalyst in this study was observed to be superior under more challenging conditions of temperature, gas space velocity and toluene content compared to those with similar Ni loads (3–5 wt%). In light of these findings, it can be concluded that the catalyst developed in this work has the potential to serve as an excellent candidate for the development of a tar-cleaning reactor that operates at lower temperatures than those of existing commercial catalysts, which could significantly enhance the overall efficiency of the gasification process. 6 Declaration of Generative AI and AI-assisted technologies in the writing process During the preparation of this work the author(s) used ChatGPT in order to improve the readability and language of the manuscript. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a Ni-mayenite/CaO catalyst was synthetized, characterized and tested as a tar reforming catalyst for a gas with a composition typical of a biomass gasification process under lower temperature conditions than commercial reforming catalysts. Moreover, a reduced Ni content of 5 wt% was used and different operating variables (temperature, steam excess and presence of H2, CO2, CO and CH4) were studied. It was confirmed that regardless the variations in the composition of the gas entering the reforming reactor, the conversion of toluene (used as tar model compound) was complete at 700 ºC and high space velocities (ca. 90000 h−1 with respect to total gas and ca. 5 kgtoluene/kgreduced cat·h) with minimal coke deposition. In addition, reaction-regeneration cycles were conducted under different regeneration temperatures and gas mixtures for the removal of the deposited solid carbon. Finally, the catalytic activity of this novel catalyst was tested against several commercial catalysts at 700 ºC, demonstrating the superior performance of the 5 % Ni-mayenite/CaO compared to any of the Ni-based commercial catalysts studied.
